Award.AwardTitle: AF: Small: Geometric Data Processing and Analysis via Light-weight Structures

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
In the current era of information, large amounts of complex data are routinely generated across science and engineering. Geometric and topological data analysis is a major component involved in organizing, analyzing, as well as utilizing the huge amount of data generated. As data becomes more complex and high dimensional, it can be computationally formidable to compute and maintain even local structures from data. Hence it has become crucial to identify and use light-weight structures that can be efficiently computed, maintained and/or manipulated; while at the same time are also sufficiently informative.

This project will focus on two such light-weight structures: the Reeb graph and the Gaussian-weighted graph Laplacian. Both of them have already been extensively used for various data analysis applications. Nevertheless, there are many theoretical and algorithmic questions about them that need to be addressed to better understand their behavior, their potential, as well as to further their practical usage. This project aims to address these issues, develop a solid theoretical foundation as well as efficient algorithms for their practical usage, and investigate novel geometric processing applications based on these two objects.

Data analysis is a fundamental problem in computational science, ubiquitous in a broad range of application fields in science and engineering. The intellectual value of this project lies not only in developing novel computational geometry algorithms and techniques, but also in transferring the results and insights to practical applications. Results from this project, especially algorithms and software, will be disseminated to a large scientific community so as to potentially produce a broader impact in scientific and engineering endeavors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the current era of information, large amounts of complex data are routinely generated across science and engineering. Geometric and topological structures have played an important role in summarizing, organizing and analyzing data. The Reeb graph and the Gaussian weighted graph Laplace operator are two "light-weight" structures that can be efficiently computed and maintained, while at the same time are still informative about input data. Specifically, the Reeb graph (and its variants) provides a succinct and meaningful summary of a real-valued function defined over a space. The Gaussian weighted graph Laplace operator can help capture important information in the space itself. These objects have already been used for various data analysis applications. To facilitate as well as to further broaden their applications in data analysis, this project explored various issues related to their theoretical understanding and practical usage. We also developed new applications of these structures in data analysis.

 

In particular, this project developed a line of work on measuring distance between the Reeb graphs. Together with students and collaborators, PI Wang developed the first general metric for measuring distance between Reeb graphs with stability guarantees, and proved that this distance is more discriminative than some other natural topological summaries of data. In a follow-up work, we established the relationship between our functional distortion distance and another natural distance for Reeb graphs, called the interleaving distance, helping to unify the different distance measures. We continued to investigate the computational complexity of this distance measure. Insights obtained from our investigation on functional distortion distance further helped us to develop a novel way to measure distance between two general finite metric graphs.

 

The PI also focused on the contour tree, a simpler variant of Reeb graph which itself already has many applications in graphics and in visualization. We discovered that if the input domain is not simply connected, a popular algorithm to construct the contour tree may fail to finish, or output a tree which is meaningless. We then showed how to compute a meaningful substitute in such cases in near linear time. Together with several collaborators, we also developed an efficient algorithm to maintain the contour tree under dynamic changes.

 

On the application front, together with her students and collaborators, PI Wang developed a generic visual analytic platform based on the contour tree, called Denali, which is publically available. We applied the idea to analyzing the conformational space of molecular simulations, as well as to study general networks. Other applications include road-network reconstruction, and the use of Gaussian weighted graph Laplacian for density uniformization and adaptation.

 

The results of this project helped to broaden the scope of geometric/topological methods for analyzing real data. The development of the project further consolidates a synergy between computational algorithms, applied mathematics and data analysis. Graduate and undergraduate students involved in this project acquired skills of developing effective and efficient computational methods based on, and justified by geometric and topological ideas.
